Some R Notes Xiaojie Gao Chapter 1 Introduction This is a place where I store some useful R notes and tips, especially for making figures in R. I may create some text my own or just copy from other places and label the origins. To write this document, I refered Authoring Books with R Markdown. So, thanks to the authors who created bookdown and wrote the awesome tutorials. Use bookdown::render_book() to render the book to HTML format.
Chapter 2 Bookdown Notes 2.1 Number and reference equations

Chapter 2 Bookdown Notes 2.1 Number and reference equations Note: I copied this section from Authoring Books with R Markdown. More tips can be found there! To number and refer to equations, put them in the equation environments and assign labels to them using the syntax (\#eq:label), e.g., \begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} (\#eq:binom) \end{equation} It renders the equation below: \[\begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} \tag{2.1} \end{equation}\] You may refer to it using \@ref(eq:binom), e.g., see Equation (2.1).
Chapter 3 General tips about R programming 3.1 Manipulating Dates 3.2 data.table

Chapter 3 General tips about R programming 3.1 Manipulating Dates 3.1.1 Day of year (DOY) to Date # note that R uses a 0 based index for dates only # this means it starts counting at 0 rather than 1 when working with dates as.Date(0, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-01-01" # note that R uses a 0 based index as.Date(1, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-01-02" # figure out the date for day 189 as.Date(189, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-07-08" 3.2 data.table Frequently Asked Questions about data.table
